Mark Moratorium Day in Baltimore

The next time a Nixon or a Johnson decides to hold
a war in Asia, ain't nobody comin'--Lance Yateman.

Vol. LXX1V, No. 33

This month's Vietnam Moratorium activites, aimed at linking high taxes to the war effort,
attracted a meager 600 foul weather friends to a
Federal Plaza rally Wednesday.
There were few adult taxpayers among the
crowd that gathered to listen to anti-war speeches and songs. Pointing to the closed blinds of
the windows of the Federal Office Building,
Baltimore Moratorium co-ordinator Mark Sissman admitted the Moratorium's failure to reach
any of the citizens of "middle America." "We
reached no one new," commented Larry Goldberg, a Hopkins Moratorium organizer. "I regard it as a total failure."

The day's activities began when about 250
people gathered at Federal Plaza for a midnight
service and the beginning of an all-night "Vigil
for Peace to Celebrate Life." The cold rain
drove all but about 50 of the participants away.
The remainder spent the night huddled in blankets and sleeping bags under the stairs and overhead walkway in the rear of the plaza. There
was another folk service at 5:30.
At about 10:30 a few people began drifting
in to the plaza, and there was some more singing
and a spontaneous "sun dance" to drive away
the rain.

Friday, April 17, 1970, Homewood, Baltimore

Marchers Move on Gordon's House
. About 75 students and two
faculty members staged a halfhour sit-in in front of the President's House last night to protest what they termed the University's complicity in the Viet Nam
war. President Gordon was out of
town.
The protestors focused their
concern on the University's Applied Physics Laboratory in Silver
Spring, Md. They demanded:
1. That the University terminate all classified defense contracts no later than July, 1971.
2. That APL maintain its
affiliation with Hopkins but
change its research priorities to
favor "socially beneficial" research, and
3. That the University establish a committee to consider
proper priorities for APL research
with four members chosen by
the Committee on APL and three
by the University Trustees.
The demonstration which
broke up at 9:45 P.M. was completely nonviolent. No attempt
was made to enter the President's
house.
The protestors were met by
Frederick DeKuyper, the President's Executive Assistant, who
sped up onto the President's driveway 15 minutes after the demonstration began. DeKuyper termed
the rally "not appropriate" because it would "embarrass Mrs.
Gordon" and advised the protestors to go elsewhere, presumably
to seek other channels .of communication.
Student leaders of the demonstration asserted that all such
channels had been closed to them.
"This was the only choice we
had," declared John Adams, one
of the APL Committee organizers.
David Chaffy told the milling and
generally lack-luster crowd, "We
won't go through committees any
more to demilitarize this University."
Political Science professor
Richard Pfeffer engaged in a heat-

ed exchange with DeKuyper at
the sit-in. At one point Pfeffer
stated, "The DeKuypers want to
make it easy to forget the war.
Fuck the DeKuypers of the
world."
He added, "We want Gordon
to know that he faces serious risks.
This campus will not stand for
war complicity."
While Pfeffer and DeKuyper
were haggling, a number of the
demonstrators cried, "Talk is bullshit."
In response, organizers
promised "action" today.
A rally is planned for the
front steps of Levering Hall at
12:30 P.M. Future plans of the

coalition of anti-war groups responsible for last night's demonstration include, a mass "bank-in"
aimed at nonviolently creating a
bottleneck at the Mercantile Trust
Company. Robert Harvey, Chairman of the Hopkins Board of
Trustees, is an official of the bank.
Yesterday was a, busy day
for campus radicals. At 10 A.M.
they talked with Marine recruiters
in Levering Hall, then proceeded
to block the front entrance to the
building from 11:30-3:30 P.M.
The recruiters left through open
rear doors.

Hopkins' Future: $4 Million Under
BY HARVEY LUKSENBURG
The tentative outline of the
University's 1970-71 budget points
to another year in the red.
The details of the budget
have not been completed yet, but
Robert Kerley, Vice-President for
Administration, disclosed some
rough figures totaling a S4 million
debt next year.
"Next year's budget will be
larger than this year's," he said.
The 1969-70 budget was approximately S125 million. "In the
Schools of Medicine and Hygiene
we expect the outside- (government) money to go up some.
The Arts and Sciences money will
probably be at the same level as
this year's."
The sharpest decline in Federal outlays will be those in support of graduate student research.
The deficit in day-to-day expenditures next year are estimated
between S4.0 and 4.25 million.
The School of Arts and Sciences
will show a S1.8 million deficit.
while the Medical School will lose
about S2.2 million.
The "inside- money, income
derived from tuition, endowments
and other sources will be slightly

lower than last year's level.
Kerley explained that the total budget's size can only be approximated because the size of
the Federal Government's financial contribution is now known at
this time.
Dire Straits
Kerley said that the reason
for Hopkins dire economic straits
is that "The University's income
is not matching the rate of the
University's cost inflation." This
inflation in costs is due to factors
like the rising salaries of the faculty and of non-professional workers.
But we °are not alone. "This
is not a unique situation to Hopkins," explained Mr. Kerley, "Most
of the major private institutions
in the nation will experience deficits. This is not a crises, but it is
a major problem. It is particularly
severe in heavily research and graduate oriented institutions. The
rises in cost of the conduct of this
kind of work exceeds the rate of
support we receive for it."
He does not see the exploitation of any new sources of revenue
within the near future. The proposals to increase the undergraduate enrollment have not been act-

Moratorium: A Requiem
The Moratorium was a bust. Informed sources report
that nationally the Moratorium Committee is on the verge
of folding for lack of funds. A schematic diagram of the
"liberal" movement reads like the complex power structure of a corporate holding company. At the top is the
New Mobilization. With seats on the New Mobe board,
yet in reality independent, are the Moratorium Committee
and the Student Mobilization Committee. -Everyone has
authority but no one has power.
In Baltimore, the Moratorium Committee planned an
all night vigil Wednesday followed by a noon rally. Then,
the SMC stepped in, and against the advice of local organizers, planned a march from Hopkins to the rally site for 10
A.M., conflicting with the vigil.
The rally failed, not only because of the weather and
interfactional mismanagement, but also because people are
simply tired of rallies. increasingly; things are polarizing
within the movement. People are either opting for violence or going out and working for a candidate. Peaceful
street protests are quickly becoming a thing of the past.
There were no businessmen to be seen at the rally in
Baltimore, and few at those in other parts of the country.
This, even though the theme of the moratorium--linking
high taxes to the war—was aimed at them. As one frustrated local organizer stated, the Moratorium is "not getting
the older people on the streets like it used to."
At Berkeley, students split into small groups for
Weatherman-style back street activities. The rally at Harvard Square drew more people--again mostly students--than
- were present on October 15. But the situation in Boston
is polarizing as well. There, where it is now fashionable
to be against the war, businessmen sport Moratorium
buttons, Students have turned to the more radical groups,
the SMC and the Mobe.
All this proves one thing—the movement is leaderless
once more. FOr a while it looked as if the coalition of antiwar groups operating under the New Mobe banner out of
Washington would be able to pull things together. It did
so in October and again in November, but in April it
appears to have lost its steam.

Hopkins as Landlord
The University's strict adherance to basic economic
rules for landlords has seriously impaired a group of community projects in the area surrounding the School for
Advanced International Studies. The University, which
claims involvement with the city that surrounds it and
points with pride to the civic projects of its students,
turns around and tells a Washington church that it must
come up with $6000 rent or watch its civic projects be
turned into a parking lot.
St. Margaret's Episcopal church and a large group of
concerned citizens, including students from American University, have invested a great deal of time and money fixing up what were but a few months ago vandal-destroyed
buildings. Yet every six months they face the possibility
of seeing their work fall to the bulldozers unless they can
raise the $1000 per month demanded by their landlord,
the Johns Hopkins University.
If Hopkins is truly concerned with the plight of the
inner city, if it actually wants to better the community
which surrounds it, here is an excellent opportunity to
show it. All involved with the projects claim that the rent
is too high, while one would assume that an idealistic
University would charge such a worthy tenant a rent
substantially below the community average. In fact it
would seem that Hopkins should jump at the opportunity
to help by simply allowing these people to use unused
buildings. We see no reason for the University charging
rent, and ask that it be rescinded immediately.

GOOD-BYE RENT STRIKE
To The Editors:
Lest I be thought a traitor to my own cause, I
wish to clarify two points connectedwith my abdication as a leader of the rent strike movement in
graduate student housing.
First, the issue of female undergraduate residence in McCoy has largely dissipated. It will
be recalled that the evident intention of the administration to lodge large numbers of female undergraduates in McCoy for an indefinite period was the
original cause of rent strike agitation. This was
not a selfish issue, since the plan was also opposed by undergraduates and seemed to be contrary to the interests of the women themselves.
In any case, if the current recommendation of
Dean Swanson is implemented, the residence of
undergraduate females in McCoy will last for
only one year, until girls are admitted into the
freshman class, and the conversion of dormitory spaces becomes feasible. The number of
female undergraduate transfers living in McCoy
next year is now expected to be small: 25-35.
If the number seeking housing turns out to be
much larger, an effort will supossedly be made
to find dormitory space for women for the coming year.
On this issue, there now seems little to do but
wait and test the administration's intentions.
Action may be necessary at some future date,
but I suspect that the female undergraduates
will themselves reject permanent residence in
McCoy, once they have established themselves
at Hopkins.
Second, the objections to the 5% rent increase
and the abolition of switchboard service have

always been somewhat tenuous. In view of the
general inflation and the recent wage increases
at Hopkins, the argument that the costs of graduate housing have increased must be accepted,
until someone launches a study of administration
efficiency. To argue that the university should
divert funds from other activities to subsidize
graduate housing is obviously divisive and not
constructive. In some departments, graduate
fellowhip stipends have been increased to meet
inflationary pressures, and this would seem the
more appropriate remedy for graduate students
to seek. Such increases may mean fewer new
graduate students, but in view of the current
job market, a reduction may be necessary anyway.
As for switchboard service, a study conducted
by students last year revealed widespread dissatisfaction with the service, and it is clear that
many students would rather take their chances
with party lines, pay phones and private homes.
If the university could work out an insurance
program with the phone company to avoid the
necessity of deposits, this complaint would soon
fade away.
For these reasons, I am no longer prepared
to sacrifice the great amount of time which
would be required to organize and co-ordinate
a rent strike. If someone else should wish to
make this sacrifice, I will gladly make available to him all information that I have on the
issue.
Raymond W. Copson

Moratorium: A Requiem
The Moratorium was a bust. Informed sources report
that nationally the Moratorium Committee is on the verge
of folding for lack of funds. A schematic diagram of the
"liberal" movement reads like the complex power structure of a corporate holding company. At the top is the
New Mobilization. With seats on the New Mobe board,
yet in reality independent, are the Moratorium Committee
and the Student Mobilization Committee. -Everyone has
authority but no one has power.
In Baltimore, the Moratorium Committee planned an
all night vigil Wednesday followed by a noon rally. Then,
the SMC stepped in, and against the advice of local organizers, planned a march from Hopkins to the rally site for 10
A.M., conflicting with the vigil.
The rally failed, not only because of the weather and
interfactional mismanagement, but also because people are
simply tired of rallies. increasingly; things are polarizing
within the movement. People are either opting for violence or going out and working for a candidate. Peaceful
street protests are quickly becoming a thing of the past.
There were no businessmen to be seen at the rally in
Baltimore, and few at those in other parts of the country.
This, even though the theme of the moratorium--linking
high taxes to the war—was aimed at them. As one frustrated local organizer stated, the Moratorium is "not getting
the older people on the streets like it used to."
At Berkeley, students split into small groups for
Weatherman-style back street activities. The rally at Harvard Square drew more people--again mostly students--than
- were present on October 15. But the situation in Boston
is polarizing as well. There, where it is now fashionable
to be against the war, businessmen sport Moratorium
buttons, Students have turned to the more radical groups,
the SMC and the Mobe.
All this proves one thing—the movement is leaderless
once more. FOr a while it looked as if the coalition of antiwar groups operating under the New Mobe banner out of
Washington would be able to pull things together. It did
so in October and again in November, but in April it
appears to have lost its steam.

Hopkins as Landlord
The University's strict adherance to basic economic
rules for landlords has seriously impaired a group of community projects in the area surrounding the School for
Advanced International Studies. The University, which
claims involvement with the city that surrounds it and
points with pride to the civic projects of its students,
turns around and tells a Washington church that it must
come up with $6000 rent or watch its civic projects be
turned into a parking lot.
St. Margaret's Episcopal church and a large group of
concerned citizens, including students from American University, have invested a great deal of time and money fixing up what were but a few months ago vandal-destroyed
buildings. Yet every six months they face the possibility
of seeing their work fall to the bulldozers unless they can
raise the $1000 per month demanded by their landlord,
the Johns Hopkins University.
If Hopkins is truly concerned with the plight of the
inner city, if it actually wants to better the community
which surrounds it, here is an excellent opportunity to
show it. All involved with the projects claim that the rent
is too high, while one would assume that an idealistic
University would charge such a worthy tenant a rent
substantially below the community average. In fact it
would seem that Hopkins should jump at the opportunity
to help by simply allowing these people to use unused
buildings. We see no reason for the University charging
rent, and ask that it be rescinded immediately.

GOOD-BYE RENT STRIKE
To The Editors:
Lest I be thought a traitor to my own cause, I
wish to clarify two points connectedwith my abdication as a leader of the rent strike movement in
graduate student housing.
First, the issue of female undergraduate residence in McCoy has largely dissipated. It will
be recalled that the evident intention of the administration to lodge large numbers of female undergraduates in McCoy for an indefinite period was the
original cause of rent strike agitation. This was
not a selfish issue, since the plan was also opposed by undergraduates and seemed to be contrary to the interests of the women themselves.
In any case, if the current recommendation of
Dean Swanson is implemented, the residence of
undergraduate females in McCoy will last for
only one year, until girls are admitted into the
freshman class, and the conversion of dormitory spaces becomes feasible. The number of
female undergraduate transfers living in McCoy
next year is now expected to be small: 25-35.
If the number seeking housing turns out to be
much larger, an effort will supossedly be made
to find dormitory space for women for the coming year.
On this issue, there now seems little to do but
wait and test the administration's intentions.
Action may be necessary at some future date,
but I suspect that the female undergraduates
will themselves reject permanent residence in
McCoy, once they have established themselves
at Hopkins.
Second, the objections to the 5% rent increase
and the abolition of switchboard service have

always been somewhat tenuous. In view of the
general inflation and the recent wage increases
at Hopkins, the argument that the costs of graduate housing have increased must be accepted,
until someone launches a study of administration
efficiency. To argue that the university should
divert funds from other activities to subsidize
graduate housing is obviously divisive and not
constructive. In some departments, graduate
fellowhip stipends have been increased to meet
inflationary pressures, and this would seem the
more appropriate remedy for graduate students
to seek. Such increases may mean fewer new
graduate students, but in view of the current
job market, a reduction may be necessary anyway.
As for switchboard service, a study conducted
by students last year revealed widespread dissatisfaction with the service, and it is clear that
many students would rather take their chances
with party lines, pay phones and private homes.
If the university could work out an insurance
program with the phone company to avoid the
necessity of deposits, this complaint would soon
fade away.
For these reasons, I am no longer prepared
to sacrifice the great amount of time which
would be required to organize and co-ordinate
a rent strike. If someone else should wish to
make this sacrifice, I will gladly make available to him all information that I have on the
issue.
Raymond W. Copson
